Title: Blimp week-end
Name: Current, Ira B.
Extent: 1 film reel (16mm); color, sound (optical, multichannel); 11:25
Abstract: Producer, U.S. Naval Reserve; photographer, LCDR Ira B. Current. Images of a U.S. Naval Reserve blimp as it launches, flies, and lands from an airstrip in Lakehurst, New Jersey. Includes footage of commanding officers, aerial views of the area, images of the crew inside the blimp, and views inside the airport hangar.
Note#1: 00:07 Film begins with instrumental music titled “The Picador” and and introduction of "Blimp Week-end" with title screen. Nine officers from Binghamton Composite Company 3-5 are seen packing a car and departing for the reserve training center; 01:06 Officers eat dinner in town and then arrive at Lakehurst, New Jersey where the reserve is located; 01:31 Several commanders walk out of a building with a sign that reads, "Commissioned Officers Mess (closed)." Lieutenant Commander Ira Current is the third man to walk out of the doorway. Film continues to show the men walking and talking around the naval reserve; 02:18 View from a moving vehicle shows a bus approaching a large, silver blimp located at the naval reserve training unit at a hangar on the airstrip. A narrator states there are four hangars and each of them are 200 feet high and 100 feet-1,000 feet in length. Each hangar covers six acres and houses up to six blimps; 03:09 Scene showing the outside of a K-ship, which is around 250 feet in length and inflated with about 456,000 cubic feet of helium gas. Film continues to show a crew of six men sitting inside the airship; 03:34 Exterior view of a blimp being towed out using a tractor. The blimp is still attached to its mooring mast; 03:51 Exterior view showing a different blimp taking off then scene changes to an interior view of the crew holding the first blimp by means of nose lines until it is ready to be released. The blimp takes off. There are aerial views of the other blimps, hangars, and administration buildings on the base; 05:18 Narrator talks about the helium storage tanks and material of the blimp which consists of three-ply rubberized cotton fabric and no internal framework; 05:50 Film continues to show the crew on the blimp. Narrator talks about the tasks the blimps were used for during World War II. He continues to talk about the benefits of using an aircraft that could hover at a slow speed and low altitude to conduct operations such as aerial photography, torpedo recovery, rescue work, aerial observation, and mine spotting; 06:47 Aerial view of a light house as the narrator states that [Finnigan Light?] on the New Jersey coast is the destination for the blimp; 07:00 Aerial view shows several smoke bombs dropped in the water to calculate wind and speed; 07:28 Interior view from the blimp showing it approaching the landing crew. The crew secures the air ship to the mooring mast using its lines; 08:09 Scene changes to views of the commanders, crew, and blimps. The same instrumental song continues to play in the background; 08:40 A tour of the base continues. Men walk around various air crafts and hangars; 09:02 Exterior views of the base during the evening time. The narrator explains that Binghamton Composite Company 3-5 feels well versed in flying the airship and leaves for the day to compare notes. Film continues to show the men driving back in their cars; 10:49 The film ends with credit scenes.
